content.scope: Defines 'State' for the purpose of Part III (Fundamental Rights)
provisions: **Government and Parliament of India** - Union executive and legislature
**Government and Legislature of States** - State executive and legislature
**All local authorities** - Municipalities, Panchayats, improvement trusts
**All other authorities** - Statutory bodies, public corporations (LIC, ONGC, etc.)
significance: Widens the scope of FR - enforceable against State only
Ensures government actions are subject to FR scrutiny
Includes government companies substantially controlled by State
content.examTips: **Key Point**: Only actions of 'State' can violate FRs. Private individuals cannot violate FRs (except Art 23-24).
content.keyCases: **Pradeep Kumar Biswas v IIT Delhi (2008)** - IIT declared as 'State' under Art 12

provisions: **Pre-constitutional laws**: If inconsistent with FR, void to extent of inconsistency
**Post-constitutional laws**: State shall not make any law that takes away or abridges FRs
**'Law' includes**: Ordinance, order, bye-law, rule, regulation, notification, custom, usage having force of law
significance: Makes FR supreme - any law violating FR is void
Judicial review power derives from this article
Protects FRs from legislative encroachment
exceptions: **Art 31A, 31B, 31C** - Create immunity for certain laws (land reforms, DPSP implementation)
**Amendments to Constitution** - Not 'law' under Art 13 (Kesavananda Bharati case)
content.examTips: **Remember**: Art 13(2) makes FR superior to ordinary laws. Parliament cannot violate FRs through ordinary legislation.
content.keyCases: **Kesavananda Bharati (1973)** - Constitutional amendments not covered under Art 13; Basic Structure doctrine established

provisions: **Equality before law** - British concept (negative); no person above law
**Equal protection of laws** - American concept (positive); equals treated equally
Applies to both citizens and non-citizens
scope: Rule of law - no arbitrary discrimination
Reasonable classification permitted - must have rational nexus with object
Applies to all State actions - legislative, executive, judicial
exceptions: **President & Governors** - Art 361 grants immunity from criminal proceedings during office
**Reasonable classification** - Permitted if based on intelligible differentia with rational nexus
content.examTips: **Most Important**: Art 14 is foundation of equality. Allows classification but not discrimination. Test: (1) Intelligible differentia (2) Rational nexus with object.
content.keyCases: **Maneka Gandhi (1978)** - Art 14 pervades all FRs; procedure must be fair, just and reasonable

provisions: **15(1)**: State shall not discriminate on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them
**15(2)**: No citizen shall be discriminated in access to shops, restaurants, hotels, public entertainment, wells, tanks, roads (public use)
**15(3)**: State can make special provisions for **women and children**
**15(4)**: State can make special provisions for **socially and educationally backward classes** (SEBCs) and **SCs/STs** (added by 1st Amendment 1951)
**15(5)**: Private educational institutions can reserve seats for SEBCs/SCs/STs except minority institutions (added by 93rd Amendment 2005)
exceptions: Special provisions for women, children permitted
Reservation for SCs, STs, OBCs permitted
Minority educational institutions protected under Art 30
content.examTips: **Critical**: Art 15(4) and 15(5) are exceptions to 15(1). Enable affirmative action. 15(4) added by 1st Amendment; 15(5) by 93rd Amendment.
content.keyCases: **Indra Sawhney (1992)** - Upheld OBC reservation; introduced creamy layer; 50% ceiling on reservation

provisions: **16(1)**: Equal opportunity in matters of public employment
**16(2)**: No discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence
**16(3)**: Parliament can prescribe residence requirement for certain state jobs
**16(4)**: Reservation for **backward classes** if inadequately represented (added 1st Amendment)
**16(4A)**: Reservation in **promotions** for SCs/STs (added 77th Amendment 1995)
**16(4B)**: Unfilled reserved vacancies can be carried forward (**consequential seniority** maintained) (added 81st Amendment 2000)
**16(5)**: Religious institutions can require employees of same religion
content.examTips: **Major Amendments**: 77th (reservation in promotion), 81st (consequential seniority), 85th (promotion with consequential seniority in SCs/STs)
content.keyCases: **M Nagaraj (2006)** - Upheld Art 16(4A) and 16(4B); but reservation in promotion requires data on backwardness and inadequate representation

provisions: **Untouchability abolished** - practice in any form forbidden
Enforcement of disability arising from untouchability is an **offence punishable by law**
Both State and private individuals bound
significance: **Only FR enforceable against private individuals** (along with Art 23-24)
Social reform measure to eradicate caste-based discrimination
Implemented through **Protection of Civil Rights Act 1955** (earlier Untouchability Offences Act 1955)
content.examTips: **Unique Feature**: Art 17 is absolute - no exceptions. Enforceable against private persons also.
content.keyCases: **State of Karnataka v Appa Balu Ingale (1993)** - Practice of untouchability in any form punishable under PCR Act 1955

provisions: **18(1)**: State shall not confer any title (except military and academic distinctions)
**18(2)**: No citizen shall accept any title from a foreign State
**18(3)**: Foreign titles not to be used by foreigners holding office of profit
**18(4)**: Foreign titles cannot be used without President's consent by citizens
exceptions: **Bharat Ratna, Padma awards** - Not titles; held constitutional in Balaji Raghavan case (1996)
**Military distinctions** - Param Vir Chakra, Maha Vir Chakra, etc.
notes: Padma awards (Bharat Ratna, Padma Vibhushan, Padma Bhushan, Padma Shri) are **honours**, not titles
Cannot be used as prefix/suffix to name (though often violated in practice)
content.examTips: **Remember**: Padma awards are NOT titles under Art 18. They are honours and don't confer any privileges.

provisions: **19(1)(a)**: Freedom of **speech and expression** (includes press, media)
**19(1)(b)**: Freedom to **assemble peacefully** without arms
**19(1)(c)**: Freedom to form **associations or unions** (includes right to strike - not absolute)
**19(1)(d)**: Freedom to **move freely** throughout India
**19(1)(e)**: Freedom to **reside and settle** in any part of India
**19(1)(g)**: Freedom to **practice any profession, occupation, trade or business**
notes: **Originally 7 freedoms** - 19(1)(f) right to property was deleted by 44th Amendment 1978
**Available to citizens only** (not to non-citizens or foreign companies)
**Not absolute** - each freedom subject to reasonable restrictions under Art 19(2) to 19(6)
restrictions: Restrictions only on grounds specified in Art 19(2) to 19(6)
**Procedure established by law** requirement (Art 21 expanded this)
content.examTips: **Critical for Exams**: Originally 7 freedoms (19(1)(a) to (g)); 19(1)(f) property right deleted in 1978. Now only 6 freedoms. Each has specific grounds for restrictions.
content.keyCases: **Romesh Thappar (1950)** - Freedom of press included in Art 19(1)(a)

provisions: **20(1)**: No **ex-post-facto law** - cannot be convicted for act not offence when done
**20(2)**: No **double jeopardy** - cannot be prosecuted and punished twice for same offence
**20(3)**: No **self-incrimination** - accused cannot be compelled to be witness against himself
scope: Available to **both citizens and non-citizens**
Protection against conviction for criminal offences only (not civil matters)
Art 20(3) protection available at investigation, inquiry, trial stages
exceptions: Tax proceedings are civil - Art 20 doesn't apply
Narco-analysis, brain-mapping violate Art 20(3) if forcibly conducted
content.examTips: **Remember 3 protections**: (1) Ex-post-facto law (2) Double jeopardy (3) Self-incrimination. All three available to citizens and non-citizens.
content.keyCases: **Selvi v State of Karnataka (2010)** - Narco-analysis, polygraph, brain-mapping violate Art 20(3) if conducted without consent

provisions: No person shall be deprived of **life or personal liberty** except according to **procedure established by law**
**Most expansive FR** - includes right to live with dignity, livelihood, health, education, environment, privacy, etc.
judicialExpansion: **Maneka Gandhi (1978)**: Procedure must be fair, just, reasonable (not arbitrary)
**Right to education** - Mohini Jain (1992); later made explicit through Art 21A
**Right to clean environment** - MC Mehta v Union (1987)
content.significance: **Most litigated article** - judicial creativity expanded scope tremendously through PIL
content.examTips: **Most Important FR**: Art 21 heart of FRs. Remember key cases: Maneka Gandhi (procedure must be fair), Puttaswamy (privacy). Art 21A (education) added via 86th Amendment.
content.keyCases: **Maneka Gandhi (1978)** - Revolutionary case; expanded Art 21; procedure must be fair, just, reasonable

provisions: State shall provide **free and compulsory education** to all children aged **6 to 14 years**
Inserted by **86th Constitutional Amendment Act 2002**
Implemented through **Right to Education Act 2009** (RTE Act)
significance: Converted DPSP (Art 45) into Fundamental Right
Makes education justiciable - can be enforced through courts
India one of few countries with education as FR
notes: **Age 6-14 years** - elementary education only (not pre-primary or higher education)
Art 51A(k) imposes **Fundamental Duty** on parents to provide education to children 6-14 years
Private schools must admit 25% children from EWS/disadvantaged (RTE Act provision)
content.examTips: **Added 2002, Implemented 2010**: 86th Amendment inserted Art 21A making education FR for age 6-14. RTE Act 2009 implements it.
content.keyCases: **Society for Unaided Schools v Union (2012)** - Upheld 25% EWS reservation in private schools under RTE Act

provisions: **22(1)**: Right to be informed of **grounds of arrest**
**22(2)**: Right to consult and be defended by **legal practitioner of choice**
**22(3)**: Arrested person must be produced before **magistrate within 24 hours**
**22(4-7)**: Safeguards against **preventive detention** (can be detained without trial max 3 months; beyond 3 months requires Advisory Board approval)
preventiveDetention: Detention to prevent future offence (not punishment for past act)
Art 22(4-7) provide safeguards but less stringent than 22(1-3)
Grounds of detention must be communicated; detenu can make representation
Advisory Board (with judges) must review within 3 months
exceptions: **Preventive detention laws**: NSA, UAPA, etc. can bypass some safeguards
Art 22(3) doesn't apply to preventive detention
content.examTips: **Two parts**: 22(1-3) protection against arrest; 22(4-7) safeguards in preventive detention. Remember 24-hour rule and Advisory Board (3 months).
content.keyCases: **AK Gopalan (1950)** - Narrow interpretation of Art 22; later overruled by Maneka Gandhi

articles.title: Prohibition of Traffic in Human Beings

provisions: **23(1)**: Traffic in human beings, **begar (forced labour)**, and other forms of **forced labour** prohibited
**23(2)**: State can impose **compulsory service for public purposes** (e.g., military conscription)
Prohibition includes slavery, bonded labour, child labour
significance: **Enforceable against State and private individuals** (one of few FRs)
Absolute prohibition - no restrictions permitted
Social reform measure
content.examTips: **Art 23 & 24 enforce against private persons** (like Art 17). Remember 'begar' means forced labour without payment.
content.keyCases: **Bandhua Mukti Morcha (1984)** - Bonded labour violates Art 23; expanded Art 21 to include right to live with dignity

provisions: No child below age of **14 years** employed in **factory, mine** or other **hazardous employment**
Enforceable against State and private employers
scope: Applies to factory, mine, hazardous work only (not all child labour)
Age limit: 14 years
Absolute prohibition - no exceptions for hazardous work
implementation: **Child Labour (Prohibition & Regulation) Act 1986** - prohibits child labour in hazardous occupations
**Child Labour Amendment Act 2016** - complete prohibition below 14 in all occupations (except family business and entertainment)
notes: Art 21A provides free education 6-14 years
Art 24 prohibits hazardous employment below 14 years
Together they aim to eliminate child labour and promote education
content.examTips: **Age 14 years, Hazardous work**: Art 24 prohibits employment below 14 in factory/mine/hazardous work. 2016 Amendment expanded to all work except family business.
content.keyCases: **MC Mehta v State of Tamil Nadu (1996)** - Directed States to identify and rehabilitate child labour; emphasized Art 21A importance

provisions: **25(1)**: Right to **freedom of conscience** and right to freely **profess, practice and propagate religion**
**25(2)**: Subject to public order, morality, health and **other FRs**
State can regulate economic, financial, political, secular activities associated with religion
scope: Freedom of conscience: Right to follow any religion or be atheist/agnostic
Profess: Right to declare religious belief
Practice: Right to perform religious acts, rituals
Propagate: Right to spread religious ideas (but NOT right to convert by force/fraud)
restrictions: Subject to public order, morality, health
State can regulate secular activities of religion
Essential religious practices protected; non-essential can be regulated
content.examTips: **3Ps**: Profess, Practice, Propagate. Available to individuals. Art 26 gives rights to religious denominations (groups). Remember 'essential religious practices' test.
content.keyCases: **Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments v Shirur Mutt (1954)** - Established 'essential religious practices' test

provisions: Every religious denomination has right to:
**26(a)**: Establish and maintain institutions for religious and charitable purposes
**26(b)**: Manage its own affairs in matters of religion
**26(c)**: Own and acquire movable and immovable property
**26(d)**: Administer such property in accordance with law
scope: Right of **religious denominations/groups** (not individuals - Art 25 for individuals)
Protects autonomy of religious institutions
State can regulate secular/administrative aspects
restrictions: Subject to public order, morality, health
content.examTips: **Religious denomination rights**: Art 26 for groups/denominations vs Art 25 for individuals. Both subject to public order, morality, health.
content.keyCases: **Sardar Syedna Taher Saifuddin v State of Bombay (1962)** - Excommunication is religious practice; State cannot interfere

provisions: No person shall be compelled to pay taxes for **promotion or maintenance of any particular religion**
Ensures State does not use tax money to promote any religion
scope: Protects individual liberty from religious tax burden
State neutrality in religious matters
Available to all persons (citizens and non-citizens)
notes: General taxes can be used for religious purposes if serving broader public purpose (e.g., managing Kumbh Mela for crowd control)
Specific taxes earmarked for one religion violate Art 27
content.examTips: **No religious taxes**: Cannot force anyone to pay tax specifically for promoting a religion. Ensures State's religious neutrality.

provisions: **28(1)**: No religious instruction in State-funded educational institutions
**28(2)**: Exception for institutions administered by State but established under endowment/trust requiring religious instruction
**28(3)**: No compulsion for students in State-recognized private institutions to attend religious instruction without consent
scope: Protects students from forced religious instruction
Applies to State-funded and State-recognized institutions
Voluntary participation permitted in private institutions with consent
notes: Fully State-funded institutions: No religious instruction at all
State-administered but privately endowed: Religious instruction permitted
Private aided/recognized: Voluntary participation with consent
content.examTips: **3 categories of institutions**: (1) Fully State-funded - no religious instruction (2) State-administered but endowed - permitted (3) Private recognized - voluntary with consent.

provisions: **29(1)**: Citizens having distinct language, script, culture have right to **conserve** the same
**29(2)**: No citizen denied admission to State-aided/State-maintained institution on grounds of religion, race, caste, language
scope: Protects cultural rights of minorities (linguistic, religious)
Right to conserve (not develop) language, script, culture
Applies to citizens only
significance: Ensures cultural diversity protection
Prevents discrimination in educational admissions
Minority rights safeguarded
content.examTips: **Right to conserve**: Art 29 protects minority's right to conserve their language/script/culture. Art 29(2) prevents admission discrimination in State institutions.
content.keyCases: **T.M.A. Pai Foundation (2002)** - Minorities have right to establish and administer educational institutions under Art 30

provisions: **30(1)**: All religious and linguistic minorities have right to **establish and administer** educational institutions of their choice
**30(1A)**: Compensation for compulsory acquisition of minority institution property must not restrict Art 30(1) right
**30(2)**: State shall not discriminate in granting aid to minority institutions
scope: Right to establish: Right to found institutions
Right to administer: Right to manage without State interference
Protects autonomy of minority institutions
restrictions: Cannot violate general laws (labor laws, etc.)
Cannot claim absolute immunity from regulation
notes: Minority institutions exempt from Art 15(5) reservation for SCs/STs/OBCs
Minority status determined by unit of State (not all-India)
Linguistic/religious minorities both covered
content.examTips: **Minority institutions special rights**: Art 30 strongest minority protection. Can establish & administer institutions. Exempt from many regulations including RTE 25% EWS quota.
content.keyCases: **T.M.A. Pai (2002)** - Landmark case on minority institutions; State determines minority status; Right to admit students part of Art 30

provisions: Right to move **Supreme Court** for enforcement of Fundamental Rights
SC empowered to issue **writs** (Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Quo Warranto, Certiorari)
**Art 32 itself a Fundamental Right** - cannot be suspended except during Emergency (Art 359)
significance: **'Soul and heart of Constitution'** - Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
Makes FRs justiciable and enforceable
Direct access to Supreme Court (no need to approach lower courts first)
Guaranteed remedy for FR violations
writs: **Habeas Corpus**: Produce person detained illegally before court
**Mandamus**: Command public authority to perform legal duty
**Prohibition**: Prevent lower court from exceeding jurisdiction
**Certiorari**: Quash order of lower court/tribunal exceeding jurisdiction
**Quo Warranto**: Inquiry into legality of person's claim to public office
notes: Art 226 gives HCs power to issue writs for FRs AND other legal rights (wider than Art 32)
Art 32 cannot be suspended even during Emergency except by Presidential order under Art 359
content.examTips: **Most Important FR**: Ambedkar called Art 32 'heart of Constitution'. Guarantees remedy for FR violations. Remember 5 writs. Art 32 (SC) only for FRs; Art 226 (HC) for FRs + other rights.
content.keyCases: **Romesh Thappar (1950)** - First case where SC used Art 32 to strike down law violating FR

articles.title: Legislation to Give Effect to FRs

provisions: Parliament (not State Legislatures) has exclusive power to make laws to give effect to certain FRs
Covers laws relating to Art 16(3), 32, 33, 34 and Part III generally
scope: Ensures uniform implementation of FRs across India
Parliament's exclusive domain (States cannot legislate)
Covers laws for residence requirement (Art 16(3)), writs (Art 32), armed forces (Art 33), martial law (Art 34)
content.examTips: **Parliament's exclusive power**: Art 35 gives Parliament exclusive power to implement certain FRs. Ensures uniformity across States.

data.summary: **Fundamental Rights (Part III, Art 12-35)** are justiciable rights enforceable through courts. They protect individual liberty against State action. **6 categories**: (1) Right to Equality (14-18), (2) Right to Freedom (19-22), (3) Against Exploitation (23-24), (4) Freedom of Religion (25-28), (5) Cultural & Educational Rights (29-30), (6) Constitutional Remedies (32). **Most important articles for exams**: Art 14 (Equality), Art 19 (6 freedoms), Art 21 (Life & Liberty - most expansive), Art 32 (Remedies - 'heart of Constitution'). **Remember**: FRs not absolute; subject to reasonable restrictions. Art 13 makes them supreme over ordinary laws.
